ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I improved my Hebrew speaking and reading and learned about Israeli culture.
I became better at both Hebrew and film analysis, expanding my Hebrew vocabulary and working through more complex literary goals in Hebrew as well. My language skills also improved.
I truly enjoyed this course. I learned so much about film analysis, film technique, Israeli society, and expanded my vocabulary in a really engaging way.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: It was interesting but there were too many blogs and response blogs, and discussion in class sometimes went a little too long on a single movie.

This course is a great L5, it's hard to ask for more. The class was fun and engaging and I feel I improved and learned a lot. Because of the openness of the instructor, all comments toward improvement have already been addressed.

There are very few weaknesses with the course. It is really enjoyable! I loved the films we watched for class and feel like I have more of a window into Israeli society through them. I love the format of the weekly blog posts and enjoyed writing my midterm and final papers. I just wish that we could take the quizzes in print. I have loved this course, learned so much, and would recommend it to anyone! Also, Shiri is just truly a fantastic teacher, who cares about her students and wants them to succeed.

The course provides a great window into Israeli society through its film (movies are fun!). The films we watched were almost all entertaining and engaging, and they provided a nice platform from which to practice and improve my Hebrew. The amount of writing for the class could be decreased slightly. I was surprised by how much work and time it demanded, but I don't regret taking the course at all.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If you are ready to work a lot, and want to watch some (mostly) sad Israeli movies, check it out. Shop it first and see what you think b/c the experience depends a lot on the other students in the class.
Absolutely. I would recommend the entire department. Hebrew is a wonderful language and they really do a great job with it.

Absolutely! I would recommend it to anyone interested in Israel or film. I find myself recommending these films to my non-hebrew speaking friends all the time. When I watch movies now, I have started to apply the film analysis skills developed in this class. I also feel like my writing and speaking skills have really improved!
